\begin{abstract}
\begin{singlespace} 

Many large U.S. employers operate Employee Hardship Funds (EHFs)--programs that distribute emergency cash grants to their workers and are funded substantially through worker donations. Despite their prevalence, these inward-oriented forms CSR remain largely unstudied. Drawing on three pre-registered studies, I examine how workers perceive EHFs and how exposure to realistic EHF communications shapes employee attitudes and behavioral intentions. A national survey of retail workers shows that employees value EHFs once described, yet awareness is limited: fewer than one in four report that their employer offers emergency cash assistance. Survey experiments at Home Depot and Walmart reveal that EHF messages can shift job attachment and union vote intentions without improving perceived financial resilience, the programs’ stated purpose. At Home Depot, exposure to information about a generous and highly promoted EHF increased job attachment and reduced interest in unionization among previously unaware workers. At Walmart, messages about a smaller, weakly promoted program produced no attachment gains and instead reduced opposition to unions. These findings suggest that workers respond to symbolic signals of organizational support independent of material security improvements, consistent with Organizational Support Theory. However, inward-oriented CSR programs that appear inadequate or inconsistent with workers’ broader job experiences may fail to generate loyalty or even backfire. EHFs function as context-dependent instruments of workplace governance.\\


\end{singlespace}
\end{abstract}

Corporate social responsibility (CSR) initiatives can serve important governance functions.  Firms use CSR to attract, motivate, and retain talent; build organizational culture; and shape worker attitudes and behavior [@ruppEmployeeReactionsCorporate2006; @turbanCorporateSocialPerformance1997; @bodeCorporateSocialInitiatives2015; @burbanoGettingGigWorkers2021; @bodeCorporateSocialInitiatives2015; @greeningCorporateSocialPerformance2000; @portocarreroEffectsShortTermCorporate2024; @toninCorporatePhilanthropyProductivity2015]. While a substantial body of empirical CSR research examines externally-facing CSR, such as charitable donations, volunteerism, and environmental commitments, firms also direct CSR initiatives inward toward their own employees [@brammerContributionCorporateSocial2007a]. Less is known about inward-oriented CSR and its role in workplace governance.

This paper examines one such widespread but unstudied practice: Employee Hardship Funds (EHFs).  EHFs are employer-administered programs providing emergency cash grants to workers facing crises like house fires, crime victimization, or natural disasters. Because worker donations provide substantial funding, EHFs blend corporate welfare with mutual aid. This hybrid structure distinguishes EHFs from standard employee benefits programs. Despite their prevalence, EHFs remain almost entirely absent from management research.

EHFs represent a contemporary form of welfare capitalism: employer-provided benefits that foster attachment and forestall unionization  [@brandesAmericanWelfareCapitalism1976; @jacobyModernManorsWelfare1998]. Yet they incorporate elements of mutual aid in which workers pool resources to assist one another, a practice historically associated with labor unions and fraternal organizations [@beitoMutualAidWelfare2000; @glennUnderstandingMutualBenefit2001; @dreyfusLabourMovementMutual1993; @webbHistoryTradeUnionism1920]. They emerge in a US labor market characterized by rising precarity, low and declining unionization, and weakened public safety nets [@hackerGreatRiskShift2019; @naiduThereAnyFuture2022; @thelenAmericanPrecariatCapitalism2019].  And they function as internal CSR--charitable programs directed toward employees rather than external stakeholders. Understanding how workers perceive and engage with EHFs, and what effects they have on workplace attachment and labor relations, carries both theoretical and practical significance.

Drawing on three pre-registered studies, I provide the first systematic evidence on EHFs and uncover surprising patterns.^[The study was pre-registered under osf.io/fhq93.  In appendix \@ref(app-PAP), I document where the execution, analysis, or reporting deviates from the pre-analysis plans.] Study 1 surveys 1,008 US retail workers nationally, revealing that workers highly value EHFs when explained, yet fewer than one in four report that their employer offers such programs. This disconnect between value and awareness suggests these programs may not function as the prominent recruitment signals that standard CSR theory would predict.

Studies 2 and 3 present survey experiments with workers a Home Depot and Walmart, two large retailers with established but programmatically distinct EHFs, to study how exposure to realistic program information affects attitudes. I find that realistic EHF messages increase job attachment and shift willingness to vote for unionization _without_ improving perceived financial security. Moreover, these effects depend on context. At Home Depot, where the program is generous and heavily promoted, exposure increased attachment and reduced union support among previously unaware workers. At Walmart, where the program is minimal and weakly promoted, identical messaging produced no attachment gains and reduced opposition to unionization. This is the opposite of presumed employer interests.

In the discussion, I develop a simple theoretical framework to extend the empirical findings. Building on Organizational Support Theory and recent work showing CSR effects depend on perceived sincerity, I argue workers evaluate inward CSR programs against two dimensions: *organizational consistency* (alignment with other workplace practices) and *situational adequacy* (reasonable fit with actual circumstances).  Programs experienced as strong on both dimensions--resonant programs--generate loyalty whereas programs lacking in both--hollow programs--may backfire.  Our results are  consistent with the interpretation that Home Depot's program resonates whereas Walmart's is hollow, but I cannot rule out alternative explanations.

This research makes five contributions. First, I introduce and document EHFs as a meaningful organizational practice, providing the first systematic evidence on  worker awareness and engagement. Second, I show that workplace practices can generate loyalty and shape union attitudes without credibly improving material circumstances, challenging assumptions about how benefits operate. Third, I demonstrate that internal CSR effects are context dependent. Fourth, I provide the first empirical evidence linking worker-oriented CSR to unionization attitudes, complementing existing work on how unionization affects firm CSR activities [@ertugrulLaborUnionsCorporate2021; @heitzPowerPeopleLabor2024].  Fifth, I propose a theoretical framework for orienting future research.

Normatively, EHFs are neither straightforwardly benevolent nor purely manipulative. EHFs may provide genuine emergency support and strengthen workplace community, or they may substitute symbolic gestures for meaningful security while discouraging collective action. They may backfire. The divergent effects at Home Depot and Walmart suggest these programs operate as context-dependent tools of labor relations management.

These findings matter for several audiences. For managers, a well-designed and promoted EHF can strengthen employee attachment, but token programs risk highlighting inadequacy rather than demonstrating care.  For scholars of CSR and human resources, EHFs reveal how firms use welfare-adjacent programs as governance mechanisms, extending our understanding to new areas of employer-employee relations. For labor relations researchers, EHFs may be part of union avoidance operating through cultural signaling rather than threats. For policy-makers and scholars of social policy, EHFs illustrate how corporations fill gaps left by weakened public safety nets, raising normative questions about whose interests these arrangements ultimately serve.

The next section describes EHFs in practice.  Section \@ref(sec-lit-review) weaves together findings from the literatures on mutual aid, welfare capitalism, and CSR to motivate the core research questions.  Sections \@ref(sec-study-1) and \@ref(sec-study-2-3) present the three pre-registered studies and results. Section \@ref(sec-framework) develops our theoretical framework.  Section \@ref(sec-conclusion) concludes, discussing implications and limitations.  Details about the pre-analysis plan, surveys, measurement, and supplementary analysis appear in the appendices.   

# EHFs in practice {#sec-ehf-bkgrnd}

Home Depot and Walmart are two of North America's largest retailers, employing approximately 420,000 and 1.6 million US workers respectively. Both compete in product and labor markets, both have faced union campaigns, and both influence retail industry standards and local labor markets [@wiltshireWalmartSupercentersMonopsony2023; @derenoncourtVoluntaryMinimumWages2025; @wartzmanStillBrokeWalmarts2022].

Both firms operate in a US labor market characterized by low levels of unionization, strained public welfare and social insurance systems, and precarious employment arrangements [@hackerGreatRiskShift2019; @naiduThereAnyFuture2022; @thelenAmericanPrecariatCapitalism2019; @weilFissuredWorkplace2014]. Economic precarity induces a "cognitive tax" that harms job performance [@meurisPriceFinancialPrecarity2018; @meurisHighCostLow2015; @leanaOrganizationalBehaviorWorking2012; @mullainathanScarcity2013], providing one business case for employer engagement around these issues. These conditions make emergency cash assistance programs potentially valuable yet also make workers vulnerable to employer influence.

Against this backdrop, Home Depot has maintained the Homer Fund since 1999 while Walmart started the Associates in Critical Need Trust (ACNT) in 2001.  Both programs are set up as non-profit charities offering cash grants for employees facing emergency expenses.  The Homer Fund makes grants of up to \$10,000 while the Walmart fund makes grants of up to \$1,500.  Beyond simple generosity, the programs differ in multiple ways, including application procedures and the frequency with which a worker can receive a grant.   Both programs solicit (tax deductible) donations from both corporate and front-line employees.  Grants to workers are tax-exempt under US law.

ACNT and Homer Fund are examples of Employee Hardship Funds. Despite operating at hundreds of large employers, EHFs remain almost entirely absent from academic research.^[@amorimScheduleUnpredictabilityHighCost2022; @reichWorkingRespectCommunity2018 are the only two peer-reviewed pieces mentioning EHFs of which I am aware.] A small practitioner literature offers testimonials and aggregate disbursement data but lacks systematic evidence on awareness rates, application patterns, approval rates, or effects on workers [@associationofdisasterrelieffundsandemployeehardshipfundsEnvironmentalScanDisaster2013; @employeerelieffundeducationgroupEnvironmentalScanDisaster2019;@aspeninstituteIlluminatingHiddenSafety2019; @rodriguezEmployeeHardshipFunds2020;@rodriguezEveryCompanyShould2020]. This paper provides the first rigorous analysis.

There is no central registry for EHFs, but I have documented over 320 companies across multiple industries operating EHFs as of January 2025, including nine of the ten largest US retailers. Many employers outsource administration to third-party nonprofits. The largest of these third parties, the Employee Assistance Foundation (EAF), claimed over 400 corporate clients and distributed over \$86 million in grants in 2020.^[Additional information about EHF regulation and third-party providers, including revenue and grant growth, is collected in appendix \@ref(app-3rd).] 

EHFs expanded rapidly during the COVID-19 pandemic, with both new program adoption and increased usage among existing programs.  Levi Strauss & Co. reported a three-fold increase in applications to their EHF in 2020 [@rodriguezEveryCompanyShould2020], with another spike in applications once coronavirus emergency aid programs expired in the US.  Home Depot suspended fundraising from employees and expedited grant processing during the pandemic emergency. EAF reported a more than tenfold increase in grant applications relative to historical averages in the first two quarters of 2020 as well as 140 new client EHFs [@employeeassistancefoundationDecadeAssistanceOffering2022].   In May 2020, amid extensive criticism of its workplace safety practices and active unionization campaigns in its warehouse and fulfillment centers, Amazon launched its \$25 million EHF.^[Amazon shuttered the program in August 2022.]  

Figure \@ref(fig:fig-HfACNTcomps) zooms in on Home Depot's Homer Fund and Walmart's ACNT using data from IRS 990 forms.  In the left panel I report net assets for each firm's nonprofit foundations.^[For tax purposes, both Homer Fund and ACNT EHFs are part of the larger Home Depot and Walmart corporate foundations, respectively.]  Both corporate charities show strong growth from 2010, but Homer Fund is operating at more than double the ACNT's size.  The right panel looks at grants to domestic individuals, my preferred indicator of EHF activity.^[The larger foundations typically focus on disbursing grants to other nonprofit and community organizations, as opposed to individuals.  The Homer Fund website reported disbursing \$17 million in 2023 EHF grants whereas the Home Depot foundation 2023 IRS form 990 reports \$19.1 million in grants to individuals.]  The Homer Fund made \$15-25 million in annual grants between 2008 and 2022 whereas ACNT typically disbursed less than \$10 million, notwithstanding Walmart's much larger corporate presence.  The Homer Fund reported making a total of over \$267 million in grants to more than 183,000 individuals over its existence. ACNT claimed to have disbursed over \$142 million over its existence to over 145,000 workers.

EHFs vary across firms in virtually all programmatic aspects including longevity, eligibility, application procedures, grant generosity, funding structure, and administration. Although all EHFs involve mutual aid, firms vary in how they communicate about programs. Home Depot promotes aggressively through social media, YouTube, and donation drives. Walmart appears to invest far less in promotion. Several major retailers, including Home Depot, highlight their EHFs in their annual Environment, Social, and Governance (ESG) reports [@thehomedepotEnvironmentalSocialGovernance2023], indicating these firms view EHFs as part of their broader CSR strategy.

EHFs are distinctive in two ways that make them particularly interesting for organizational research. First, they combine employer control with worker funding---employers create the infrastructure but workers are asked to provide money, creating a hybrid of corporate welfare and peer mutual aid. Second, EHFs can extend to contingent workers excluded from traditional benefits, potentially serving as a flexible governance tool in fissured employment relationships. There are examples consistent with this interpretation. Amazon restricted its EHF to "Amazon Flex Delivery Partners, Delivery Service Partner Delivery Associates, Temporary Associates employed by eligible staffing agencies, and drivers of eligible line haul partners," i.e., non-standard, temporary contract labor.  EAF updated its EHF program guidelines, recommending that employers "include contractors, furloughed employees, and franchise employees" in their EHF schemes [@employeeassistancefoundationDecadeAssistanceOffering2022].

# Understanding EHFs: welfare capitalism, mutual aid, and contemporary labor relations {#sec-lit-review}

Employee Hardship Funds blend elements from distinct organizational and social traditions. Understanding their potential effects requires situating them within three intersecting literatures: employer-sponsored welfare capitalism, worker mutual aid, and corporate social responsibility as a governance mechanism.

## Welfare capitalism and employer-provided benefits

EHFs can be viewed as a contemporary iteration of welfare capitalism.  In the early 20th Century, some employers provided workers significant amenities beyond wages---housing, healthcare, recreation, religious instruction, and emergency assistance---to attract and retain labor and forestall unionization [@brandesAmericanWelfareCapitalism1976;@jacobyModernManorsWelfare1998].  Large industrial firms created employer-sponsored "company unions" that substituted for independent unions' social and mutual aid functions but lacked any independent voice around wages, staffing, and benefits [@brandesAmericanWelfareCapitalism1976]. The logic is straightforward: when benefits are tied to continued employment, they increase switching costs and strengthen attachment [@baronEmploymentEconomicSocial2012]. Firms routinely use compensation strategically to preempt union organizing, producing the union "threat effect" [@farberNonunionWageRates2005; @rosenTradeUnionPower1969; @taschereau-dumouchelUnionThreat2020].

EHFs extend this tradition, but with minimal employer risk.  Unlike the company housing and hospitals of historical welfare capitalism, EHFs impose limited costs. Most funding comes from tax-deductible worker donations, and programs scale flexibly. This makes EHFs an attractive governance tool. They appear to address worker needs while maintaining employer control and requiring modest financial commitment.

## Mutual aid and worker solidarity

In EHFs, workers donate money that is then distributed to fellow workers in crisis. This structure evokes the long tradition of worker mutual aid in which workers pool resources to assist one another during hardship [@beitoMutualAidWelfare2000; @glennUnderstandingMutualBenefit2001; @dreyfusLabourMovementMutual1993]. Historically, workers themselves created and controlled mutual aid organizations.  These organizations coalesced around shared occupation, region, or ethnicity and created dense social networks and organizational capacity [@ismayTrustStrangersFriendly2018]. Many evolved into labor unions [@webbHistoryTradeUnionism1920; @bacharachMutualAidUnion2018; @jarleyUnionsSocialCapital2005] or served as organizing structures when unions were suppressed [@morrisCriminalConspiracyEarly1937; @blochVoluntaryAssociationsCorporate2017]. Unions continue to maintain emergency aid programs and insurance schemes to recruit, retain, and support members [@hertel-fernandezWhyPublicSector2021]. 

EHFs differ fundamentally from traditional mutual aid. Workers neither organize nor direct EHFs, and in most programs need not donate to receive benefits. EHFs are employer-specific, lack the cross-firm networks that characterized fraternal organizations, and do not build organizational capacity among workers. Some programs (including the Homer Fund) require workers to petition supervisors for grant support, embedding aid-seeking in hierarchical relationships rather than horizontal networks.  Nevertheless, EHFs appropriate the rhetoric and structure of mutual aid and may connect with the same "social custom" motivations associated with unions [@naylorEconomicTheoryOpen1993].

This distinction creates theoretical ambiguity. If EHFs foster a sense of mutual support and solidarity, they might strengthen collective identity in ways that build a "community of fate" and support unionization [@ahlquistInterestOthersOrganizations2013]. Workers might interpret EHFs as evidence that collective pooling of resources improves their situation, making union appeals more attractive. Alternatively, if workers attribute EHFs to employer benevolence rather than collective action or if EHFs substitute for union benefits, EHFs might reduce perceived need for unions.

## CSR and job attachment

A large literature examines how CSR shapes worker attitudes and behavior. Research distinguishes between external CSR (charitable donations, environmental commitments, community voluntarism) and internal CSR including HR practices, employee training and well-being programs  [@brammerContributionCorporateSocial2007a; @farooqMultiplePathwaysWhich2017; @hawnMindGapInterplay2016; @elakremiHowEmployeesPerceive2018].
  
External CSR attracts value-aligned workers and reduces wages required to attract high performers [@brekkeAttractingResponsibleEmployees2008; @greeningCorporateSocialPerformance2000; @turbanCorporateSocialPerformance1997; @jonesWhyAreJob2014; @burbanoSocialResponsibilityMessages2016; @wilmersValuesInequalityProsocial2022a].  CSR can increase worker identification with the firm [@ruppEmployeeReactionsCorporate2006; @brammerContributionCorporateSocial2007a], strengthen attachment to coworkers [@bodeCorporateSocialInitiatives2015], and reduce turnover [@portocarreroEffectsShortTermCorporate2024]. Experiments in labs and online labor markets find that information about employer charitable activities increases worker productivity [@toninCorporatePhilanthropyProductivity2015], elicits unpaid effort [@burbanoGettingGigWorkers2021; @cassarJobMissionSubstitute2019], and reduces willingness to engage in misconduct [@burbanoMitigatingGigRemote2022].

CSR effects depend on whether workers perceive managerial motivations as sincere and consistent with other organizational practices [@grantGivingTimeTime2012; @cassarIntentionsDoingGood2021; @ashrafSocialIncentivesOrganizations2018]. When CSR appears instrumental or inconsistent with working conditions, effects weaken or reverse [@burbanoMitigatingGigRemote2022; @amengualTrueMotivesProsocial2021; @listWhenCorporateSocial2021; @gatignon-turnauMisUsingEmployeeVolunteering2015; @zhaoInfluenceCorporateSocial2022].

EHFs occupy ambiguous territory. They are formally charitable yet directed internally, combining elements of job amenities and mutual aid. Social identity theory predicts that in-group programs should should produce stronger attachment than external charity [@linModelingCorporateCitizenship2010], though empirical support is mixed [@farooqMultiplePathwaysWhich2017].

## Research questions and hypotheses
These literatures suggest several lines of inquiry, but also areas of uncertainty where empirical evidence is especially valuable. I frame these research questions as testable hypotheses.

- **H1 (Financial Security):** EHFs are designed and promoted as programs to improve worker financial resilience during emergencies. If they function as intended, exposure to EHF messaging should improve workers' sense of financial security.

- **H2 (Awareness):** If EHFs function as tools for attracting and retaining value-aligned workers (as CSR theory suggests), then employers should promote them widely and there should be broad awareness among workers about EHF programs at their own employer and at competing firms.

- **H3 (Attachment):** Both welfare capitalism and CSR literatures predict that benefits and CSR programs increase job attachment. EHFs combine both elements. EHF messages should strengthen job attachment.

- **H4 (Unionization):** Theory is ambiguous. Welfare capitalism suggests EHFs should reduce union support by providing benefits that unions might otherwise secure. But the mutual aid structure may increase receptivity to unions by demonstrating collective action. The direction likely depends program framing and design.

- **H5 (Contingency):** CSR research shows effects depend on perceived authenticity and consistency with organizational practices. We should expect similar contingency with EHFs. Programs that are more generous, heavily promoted, and culturally integrated should produce stronger effects than token programs.

Table \@ref(tab:tab-hypotheses) summarizes these hypotheses for ease of reference. Note that H1-H3 represent predictions from existing theory applied to the EHF context. H4 acknowledges theoretical ambiguity. H5 is less a hypothesis than a boundary condition suggested by prior CSR research. Of course, with data from only two firms, we can only observe whether effects differ between firms with different EHF characteristics, a descriptive quantity. The empirical contribution lies not in testing novel theory, but in establishing basic facts about a widespread but unstudied practice and documenting effects that existing theory does not clearly predict.

```{r tab-hypotheses, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, results='asis'}

#library(tibble)

  "H4", "Exposure to EHF messaging reduces support for unionization.",
```

# Study 1: EHF awareness and attitudes among US retail workers {#sec-study-1}

Despite operating at hundreds of large employers, EHFs remain unstudied. Do workers know these programs exist? Do they value them? Study 1 provides the first systematic evidence on worker awareness, engagement, and preferences.

I focus on retail workers for three reasons. First, retail employs over 16 million Americans, making it one of the largest US employment sectors. Second, nine of the ten largest US retailers maintain EHFs, yet no research has examined worker awareness or attitudes toward these programs. Third, if EHFs function as governance tools or recruitment mechanisms, workers in this competitive, high-turnover industry should be aware of them. The industry's low wages, limited benefits, and recent unionization campaigns make it an ideal context for studying EHFs as governance tools.

## Sample and methods

I surveyed US retail workers through CloudResearch in February 2025, restricting the sample to those who confirmed current retail employment and passed attention checks, producing `r nrow(genpop)` valid responses.^[Respondents with duplicate IP addresses reporting identical demographic values were also excluded.]  I constructed post-stratification weights using 2024 American Community Survey data for retail workers to address potential selection bias.^[Weights adjust for gender, race, and education to match the employed retail workforce nationally. All descriptive statistics reported below use weighted calculations.] Sample demographic descriptions appear in Appendix \@ref(app-genpop-survsum), but I note that the unweighted sample was diverse (37% non-white, 51% male) and largely comprised of hourly workers (83%).

## Measuring EHF awareness

I measured EHF awareness by embedding "emergency cash assistance to help in unexpected hard times" in a list of potential job amenities, minimizing demand effects. Later, after explaining EHFs, I asked directly whether respondents had heard of such programs and whether their employer had one. These measures capture worker beliefs; I cannot confirm the accuracy of reports about employers' EHFs in Study 1.

## Results: limited awareness despite expressed interest

**Finding 1: low awareness of EHF programs**
```{r genpop-awareness-calcs, echo=FALSE}

          #applied.prop = survey_mean(HF_applied=="Yes", na.rm=T),

got_claim <- genpop_joint %>%
```

Using the list-based measure, I find that `r round(100*genpop_aware_tab$got.ehf.prop)`% (se = `r round(100*genpop_aware_tab$got.ehf.prop_se)`%) report that their current employer offers emergency cash assistance. When asked directly after EHFs are explained, `r round(100*genpop_aware_tab$claim.ehf.prop)`% (se = `r round(100*genpop_aware_tab$claim.ehf.prop_se)`%) claim their employer has such a program ($p =$ `r round(got_claim$p.value,2)` for the difference).  For context, `r round(100*genpop_aware_tab$aware.prior.prop)`% (se = `r round(100*genpop_aware_tab$aware.prior.prop_se)`%) said that they had heard of EHF programs prior to taking the survey. In a separate, Fall 2022 survey of front line workers in five industries (including retail), @ahlquistWERNWorkersSurvey2023 found that only 13% of retail workers reported that their employer had an emergency cash grant program using the same list-based question method.  

I also tested knowledge about EHFs at specific employers. Figure \@ref(fig:fig-genpop-beliefs) shows retail worker beliefs about whether six major retailers operate EHFs.^[The employers were Costco (no), Disney (yes), Home Depot (yes), Kohl's (yes), Starbucks (yes), Walmart (yes).] Regardless of whether respondents' own employer has an EHF, large majorities express ignorance about programs at major employers. Even for Walmart and Home Depot, which have operated EHFs for over 20 years, fewer than 30% of workers correctly identified these firms as having programs.

Workers whose own employer has an EHF are somewhat more likely to correctly identify programs at other retailers, but knowledge remains limited. This contradicts H2 (awareness). If EHFs served as significant tools for attracting value-aligned workers, we would expect much higher awareness both of one's own employer's program and of programs at competing firms. EHFs operate with low salience in retail labor markets.

**Finding 2: Strong interest in EHFs...once explained**

Despite limited awareness, workers respond enthusiastically when EHFs are explained. All respondents saw a brief EHF description as part of a direct awareness question.^[
The question wording was "Some companies offer their employees programs called "Employee Hardship Funds". Employee Hardship Funds provide emergency cash to a company's workers if they face unexpected financial hardships, such as a house or apartment fire. The emergency money from the Employee Hardship Fund is not a loan and does not have to be repaid. The money in the fund comes directly from donations from the company's own workers. Before taking this survey, had you ever heard of Employee Hardship Funds?"]

After providing this description, I asked about their current employer's program and their level of support. Figure \@ref(fig:fig-genpop-support) shows strong enthusiasm: `r round(100*support_sum$prop[1])`% of workers whose employer has an EHF are 'extremely supportive' of maintaining it, and `r round(100*support_sum$prop[4])`% of those without one strongly support creating one ($p =$ `r round(tt$p.value,2)` for difference).  

I asked about willingness to donate to an EHF, `r round(100*genpop_engage_sum$donte_new)`% would donate, if their employer created an EHF, with the modal response being "regular donations of less than \$20." Workers see value in pooling resources to help coworkers.  

```{r fig-genpop-support, fig.show="hold", out.width="80%", fig.cap="Worker support for creating (R) or maintaining (L) an EHF at current job."}
ehf_support_genpop
```

**Finding 3: EHFs valued as a job amenity**

To assess how workers value EHFs relative to other amenities, I presented a hypothetical job scenario and a series of potential job amenities:

> "Imagine another retailer was hiring, paying the same wage you are earning at [Employer].  The new job has a commute that is 10 minutes longer but has better benefits.  How seriously would you consider this offer, if the better benefits were [Benefit]?"

I then asked respondents to rate their interest in the hypothetical job (not at all seriously, somewhat seriously, very seriously).
Figure \@ref(fig:fig-genpop-prefs) shows results. "Emergency cash offered during hard times" ranks second only to paid time off in generating very serious interest in switching employers. Notably, EHFs are rated as more attractive than parental leave or union representation. At median hourly wages in our sample (\$16/hour), the additional 20-minute daily commute implies forgoing approximately `r paste("$",round(1/3*genpop_engage_sum$wage_med,2), sep="")` in earnings per round trip to work.^[I focused on difference in commute time rather than a difference in hourly wage rates because shift availability and scheduling practices are highly variable within and across retailers [@harknettImprovingHealthEconomic2021;@schneiderHardTimesRoutine2021].] That workers would seriously consider this trade off for an EHF suggests they perceive substantial value in these programs, even though many are unaware whether their current employer already offers one.

```{r fig-genpop-prefs, fig.show="hold", out.width="80%", fig.cap="Degree of interest in a new job with longer commute but better amenities."}
amenity_plot_w_gp
```

**Finding 4: workers want a voice in the EHF**

Finally, I asked respondents who did not report having an EHF how much control workers _should_ have if their employer launched such a program.  Figure \@ref(fig:fig-genpop-control) indicates that large majorities preferred an EHF arrangement in which workers have a voice in running the fund.  The modal response is a shared governance model with input from both the employer and workers; only `r round(100*control_sum$prop[1])`% want complete employer control.

This preference aligns with broader evidence of strong latent worker demand for voice over workplace decisions [@mazumderWhatAmericansWant2024; @kochanWorkerVoiceAmerica2019a]. It also suggests tension between how workers would prefer EHFs to operate (participatory mutual aid) and how they actually function (employer-controlled programs).

```{r fig-genpop-control, fig.show="hold", out.width="80%", fig.cap= "Workers' preferred locus of EHF control"}
genpop_ehf_cntrl
```

## Discussion

Study 1 reveals a puzzle: workers value emergency assistance yet remain largely unaware of EHFs. This contradicts H2 and challenges standard CSR theory in which such programs function as recruitment signals. If employers were using EHFs to attract value-aligned workers, awareness should be far higher.

Three mechanisms might explain low awareness. First, many employers (or their agents) only minimally promote EHFs---consistent with Walmart's limited effort. Second, workers may encounter information but fail to retain it when bundled with other onboarding messages, especially if they don't anticipate needing emergency funds (optimism bias). Third, workers may recognize charitable activities or program names ("Homer Fund") but not connect them to "emergency cash assistance."

# Studies 2 \& 3: experimental evidence from Home Depot and Walmart {#sec-study-2-3}

Study 1 documented that retail workers are largely unaware of EHF programs but value them highly when explained. Studies 2 and 3 expose workers at two large US retailers to realistic EHF messages, examining whether the message affects worker attitudes. When workers receive messages about their employer's EHF, how does that information affect their sense of financial security, attachment to the workplace, and attitudes toward unionization?

I focus on Home Depot and Walmart because both firms operate well-established, in-house EHFs with over 20 years of continuous operation, making them mature programs that workers have had ample opportunity to encounter. They are extremely large employers, which makes recruiting a survey sample feasible.   By concentrating on specific firms I can produce context-specific survey experiments. 

These firms' EHFs differ in generosity, promotion, and cultural integration, allowing exploration of boundary conditions (H5). Two cross-sectional studies cannot isolate which features account for differential effects. Home Depot and Walmart differ in multiple ways, including wages, scheduling practices, workforce composition, and organizational culture. This research design selects two firms facing that same competitive environment, but with different EHF programs. The aim is to evaluate whether there is any context-dependence in EHF effects.  Effect variation is relevant to existing theories of inward CSR and necessary to justify more research with longitudinal or multi-firm designs.

## Program characteristics

Home Depot operates the Homer Fund, established in 1999. The program offers grants up to \$10,000 per qualifying event with day-one eligibility and no limits on repeat applications. In fiscal year 2022 (the year of our survey), the Homer Fund distributed $21.2 million to over 12,000 workers [@thehomedepotEnvironmentalSocialGovernance2023].

Home Depot actively promotes the program through social media, YouTube, donation drives, and integration into corporate social responsibility messaging. Store locations compete in fundraising campaigns. The Homer Fund claims that a "majority of contributions" come from front line associates, emphasizing the mutual aid component.^[ [https://corporate.homedepot.com/page/homer-fund-0](https://corporate.homedepot.com/page/homer-fund-0) ] @sullMeasuringCultureLeading2019, using online postings to develop measures of corporate culture, rank Home Depot at the 77th percentile for "collaboration" and 48th percentile for "respect", suggesting relatively high trust and teamwork compared to other retailers.

Walmart operates the Associates in Critical Need Trust (ACNT), established in 2001. The program offers a maximum \$1,500 in total grants over a rolling five-year period, regardless of qualifying events.  ACNT eligibility requires at least 90 days of employment tenure. In recent years, ACNT distributed under \$10 million annually despite Walmart employing nearly four times as many US workers as Home Depot. Walmart provides minimal promotion---no dedicated videos, limited social media presence, and no evidence of donation drives comparable to Home Depot's.^[Interestingly, Walmart matches employee donations to the Walmart political action committee 2:1 with corporate donations to the ACNT. In 2015, the Federal Election Commission rejected a challenge to this practice.  In our sample, fewer than 1% of respondents reported making a contribution to the Walmart PAC.] Walmart's corporate culture ranks at the 15th percentile for respect and 37th percentile for collaboration [@sullMeasuringCultureLeading2019]. The firm is known for cost control rather than investment in employees [@cascioDecencyMeansMore2006; @wartzmanStillBrokeWalmarts2022; @reichWorkingRespectCommunity2018], notwithstanding a recent push to raise compensation through a "voluntary minimum wage" [@derenoncourtVoluntaryMinimumWages2025].
 
Table \@ref(tab:tab-ehf-comparison) summarizes these differences. Under H5, EHF messages should produce stronger effects at Home Depot, where the program is more generous and culturally integrated.

## Respondent recruitment and sample description 

I recruited participants independently for each firm using targeted Meta advertising (Facebook, Instagram, Threads), an approach validated for sampling retail workers [@schneiderWhatFacebookTool2019; @growFacebooksAdvertisingData2022]. Ads targeted US users aged 18+ whom Meta identified as employees of Home Depot or Walmart. Those included in the analysis confirmed current employment at Home Depot or Walmart, passed attention checks, and were randomly assigned to experimental conditions. Those completing the survey entered a raffle for prizes. While this produces some selection bias relative to a random sample, the direction is unclear and the method performs well in similar contexts [@schneiderWhatFacebookTool2019; @zhangQuotaSamplingUsing2020; @neundorfHowImproveRepresentativeness2023]. Critically, targeted social media recruitment is the only cost-effective method for generating large matched worker-employer samples independent of employer cooperation.

Study 2 (Home Depot) fielded September–October 2021 ($N=515$). Study 3 (Walmart) fielded October–December 2024 ($N=980$). The three-year gap reflects funding constraints; I address timing concerns in detail below. Both samples are almost entirely hourly workers with average age 47 and over 75% white. The Home Depot sample is 56% male; Walmart is 78% female. Following @schneiderWhatFacebookTool2019, I construct raking weights using Meta-reported age and gender distributions for users employed at each firm. Weights are used for descriptive statistics but not experimental analysis. Full demographic details appear in Appendices \@ref(app-survsum-uw) and \@ref(app-wmt-survsum).

Workers entering our experiment already aware of their employer's EHF ("pre-exposed") differ systematically from the unaware, especially in job tenure. The survey experiments test whether a one-time exposure to an EHF message shifts attitudes, not how gradual, organic awareness shapes attachment over time or how the introduction of a new program might work. I therefore examine treatment effect heterogeneity by pre-exposure status.

## Experimental design

In both studies, I randomly assigned respondents to receive either information about their employer's EHF or to control conditions receiving no EHF information. The core design is similar across studies, with some refinements in Study 3.

The experiment in Study 2 (Home Depot) included three conditions:

* Control ($N=164$): No information about Homer Fund
* _Text_ treatment ($N=197$): Brief, neutral textual description of Homer Fund
* _Video_ treatment ($N=154$): Actual Home Depot-produced promotional video

The text treatment stated: 

> "Your employer, The Home Depot, maintains a program called the Homer Fund. The Homer Fund combines donations from workers like you with money from the Home Depot corporation. The Homer Fund uses this money to offer cash grants of up to $10,000 to Home Depot employees in times of unexpected financial hardship like a natural disaster, illness, or death in the family."

Neutral textual descriptions do not reflect how employers actually communicate with their employees.  As a more realistic intervention, I ask respondents in the video treatment to watch a professionally-produced testimonial video featuring a Home Depot employee who received Homer Fund assistance during a serious illness.  The video emphasizes emotional themes of family crisis and coworker support.  Figure \@ref(fig:fig-ray), panel (a) displays a still image.^[The video is publicly visible here: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qF-HBoySMe](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qF-HBoySMe) and here: [https://corporate.homedepot.com/news/foundation-and-community/homer-fund-celebrates-20-years-giving-rays-story](https://corporate.homedepot.com/news/foundation-and-community/homer-fund-celebrates-20-years-giving-rays-story). The video runs 2:41.]

```{r fig-ray, echo=FALSE, fig.cap = "Screen stills of the video treatments", fig.subcap = c("Home Depot", "Walmart"), out.width="50%", fig.align = "center"}
knitr::include_graphics( c(
  here('4_output', 'plots','RaysStory.jpeg' ),
  here('4_output', 'plots','Rays_story_wmt.png')
  )
)
```

The Study 3 (Walmart) experiment also included three conditions:

 * Pure control ($N=260$): No information
 * Placebo control ($N=254$): Video about Walmart's acquisition of Vizio
 * Video treatment ($N=466$): Adapted EHF video

Note that Study 3 concentrates on a video vignette treatment for the Walmart sample, omitting the text treatment based on results from the Study 2. Because Walmart does not produce promotional videos for the ACNT and for close comparability to the Home Depot experiment, I produced my own video message that mirrors the Homer Fund video's structure, script, and production style. I hired an actor matching Ray's demographics (white male, approximately age 50) and adapted the script to Walmart/ACNT context. The Walmart video is 41 seconds shorter (trimming only visual transitions, not spoken content). Figure \@ref(fig:fig-ray), panel (b) displays a still image from the beginning of the video.^[Videos can be seen here: [placebo video](https://tinyurl.com/EHF-Study3-placebo); [treatment (solidarity card)](https://tinyurl.com/EHFStudy3-solidarity); [treatment (charity card)](https://tinyurl.com/EHF-Study3-charity).]   

Respondents were randomly divided between treatment and control. To address concerns that effects might reflect generic video exposure rather than EHF content, I added a placebo condition in Study 3. Control respondents were randomized to either receive no video (pure control) or watch a video with identical production values but unrelated content (Walmart's acquisition of Vizio). 

Manipulation checks (see Appendix \@ref(app-manip-wmt)) confirm that the video treatment did indeed increase respondent awareness of the ACNT, as expected whereas the placebo had no effect. Similarly, the ACNT video successfully increased respondents' behavioral willingness to donate to the EHF, as expected, whereas the placebo had no effect (see Appendix \@ref(app-donate-wmt)). I therefore combine the pure and placebo controls in analysis below.^[Within the Study 3 treatment arm, I also randomized between two variations of the video (different title card before pressing play, all other content identical): "charity" framing emphasizing charitable donations vs. "solidarity" framing emphasizing supporting fellow Walmart workers. This pre-registered sub-experiment tested whether solidarity vs. charity framing matters. I found no detectable differences for any outcome (Appendix \@ref(app-framing)), so I pool all treated respondents in the main text.]

Immediately after the experimental condition, all respondents answered questions measuring our three key outcomes: financial security, job attachment, and union support. 

## Outcome measurement

I outline measurement of key outcomes here, with extensive detail and justification appearing in Appendix \@ref(app-measurement).  All ordered categorical variables are re-scaled to the $[0,1]$ interval.

I measure _subjective financial security_ adapting the Federal Reserve's standard question from the Survey of Household Economics and Decision-making question [@boardofgovernorsofthefederalreservesystemEconomicWellBeingHouseholds2023]: "How confident are you that you could come up with \$400 if an unexpected need arose within the next month?" The responses on a 4-point scale range from "certain I could not" to "certain I could". This widely-used indicator of subjective financial resilience asks about the exact type of hardships that EHFs claim to address [@groverWhat400Emergency2021].

I use multiple indicators of _job attachment_:

* Loyalty to coworkers (4-point scale, "none at all" to "a lot")
* Loyalty to employer (same scale)
* Willingness to recommend employer (5-point scale, "definitely would not recommend" to "certainly would recommend")
* Quit intentions (Study 3 only; 5-point scale from "not at all likely" to "extremely likely", reverse-scaled)

For concision, I express these variables as a job attachment index.  I conducted exploratory factor analysis on these items in both samples. Results showed a single dominant factor explaining 64% (Study 2) and 54% (Study 3) of variance. Internal consistency reliability was acceptable (Cronbach's $\alpha$ = 0.84 at Home Depot and 0.81 at Walmart). Following our pre-registered plan, I used factor scores on this unique factor as our index, where higher scores indicate greater job attachment.^[Appendix \@ref(app-attachmentindex) provides complete psychometric details including factor loading, reliability statistics, and convergent/discriminant validity evidence. Results analyzing individual items separately (Appendix \@ref(app-cov) and \@ref(app-full-wmt)) show consistent treatment effects across all components, supporting the composite index approach.]

Our indicator of union support is the standard union vote intention question from industrial relations research [@kochanWorkerVoiceAmerica2019a; @ahlquistRiseUnionCurious2024; @freemanWhatUnions1984]: "If an election were held today to decide whether employees like you should be represented by a union at [EMPLOYER], would you vote for the union or against the union?" Responses are in \{for the union, against the union, not sure\}. The union vote question taps a concrete behavioral intention, not an abstract attitude. The question reflects the union certification voting process in the US, giving it strong face validity.^[See @ahlquistRiseUnionCurious2024 for a discussion comparing this question to more generic union approval questions.  Ahlquist et al. also provide evidence that that the "DK" responses for this question generally reflect actual ambivalence, rather than satisficing.]

In Study 3 only, I also asked: "What percent of your coworkers do you think would vote FOR a union if there were an election today?" (0-100 scale). This captures perceptions of collective support distinct from personal voting intentions.

## Analytic approach

The main quantities of interest are the average treatment effects (ATE) for each of the EHF treatment relative to control for each of the outcome variables. A key design challenge is that significant proportions of respondents in both studies were already aware of their employer's EHF before our experiment.  I therefore examine treatment effect heterogeneity by pre-exposure status.^[Pre-exposure can also be viewed through the lens of compliance with treatment assignment; the pre-exposed are "always takers" while the un-exposed are "compliers".  Since I have direct measures of pre-exposure, however, the heterogeneous effects approach is more natural.] 

Pre-exposure to EHF information is not randomly assigned, but that is not a quantity of causal interest.  Rather pre-exposure is a trait that may  moderate experimental treatment effects.  The assumption needed to sustain a causal interpretation of experiment treatment is that pre-exposure to information about the EHF is independent of potential outcomes, conditional on treatment and relevant covariates. This is plausible given pre-exposure primarily reflects job tenure (which I condition on) and the list-based awareness measure precedes treatment.  Measuring awareness before treatment could prime respondents, but three facts suggest this is not a serious concern: the measurement is subtle (embedded in a benefits list), pre-exposed and unexposed workers differ systematically in outcomes and treatment effects, and any priming would bias results toward zero. However, I cannot definitively rule out that pre-exposed and unexposed workers differ on unobserved characteristics may independently predict both awareness and our outcomes.

I produce regression-based estimates of causal effects using OLS with robust standard errors for financial security and job attachment and multinomial logistic regression for the trichotomous union vote. I report three models for each outcome: one that includes only the experimental treatment indicators, providing ATE estimates; one that adds a treatment-by-awareness interaction term, and a third that also includes a suite of pre-registered pre-treatment covariates, including predictors of awareness.^[Full reporting of the covariate coefficient estimates appears in appendices]  The latter two specifications allow us to assess effect heterogeneity. 

## Results: Study 2 (Home Depot)
I begin by examining treatment effects on each outcome, then assess heterogeneity by pre-exposure.

### Financial security

Recall that H1 predicts EHF information should improve workers' sense of financial security. Figure \@ref(fig:fig-finsec) displays the distribution of responses by treatment condition;  vertical lines represent 95% confidence intervals.  Just under 40% of Home Depot respondents expressed concern about their ability to meet this financial challenge, in line with recent estimates [@boardofgovernorsofthefederalreservesystemEconomicWellBeingHouseholds2023]. EHF information does not affect financial security. If anything, the video treatment produces slightly more pessimism (though not statistically distinguishable from zero).

```{r fig-finsec, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Subjective financial security by treatment status for the Home Depot sample", out.width="70%", fig.align='center'}

temp<-here::here('2_code', 'THD', '4_insecurity_summary_plots.R')
source(temp)
rm(temp)
p.ord
```

 Table \@ref(tab:tab-finsec) confirms this null finding across all specifications. Neither text nor video treatment shifts financial security perceptions. Interestingly, workers pre-exposed to the Homer Fund report higher levels of financial security by about 0.5 standard deviations, or half the average distance between outcome categories, even after controlling for tenure and other predictors of awareness. This correlation could reflect the Homer Fund improving security, but absent experimental effects, the relationship is likely spurious (e.g., more financially secure workers stay employed at Home Depot longer or pay more attention to benefits information).  I also examined an alternative measure—self-reported difficulty paying monthly bills—and found identical null results (Appendix \@ref(app-bills)).  Across both measures, exposing Home Depot workers to Homer Fund information does not shift their subjective financial security. H1 is not supported.

```{r tab-finsec, echo=FALSE, tab.cap="OLS regression estimates of treatment effects on subjective financial security at Home Depot."}

temp<-here::here('2_code', 'THD', 'insecurity_models.R')
source(temp)
rm(temp)
model_print_uw

```




### Job attachment

Table \@ref(tab:tab-aithd-models) presents OLS regression estimates of treatment effects on the job attachment index.  On average, the text treatment had no detectable effect, but the video treatment increased average job attachment by 0.28 on the index scale, or about 27% of a control group standard deviation.  I also uncover important heterogeneity by pre-exposure status.  Those pre-exposed to the EHF were significantly more positive about their Home Depot job than the un-exposed by about 60% of a standard deviation, even accounting for predictors of EHF awareness. 

```{r tab-aithd-models, echo=FALSE, tab.cap="OLS regression estimates of treatment effects on job attachment at Home Depot."}
temp<-here::here('2_code', 'THD', '6_loyalty_models.R')
source(temp)
rm(temp)
model_print_thd_uw_attachment
```

In contrast to findings for financial security, I recover positive and significant treatment effects for job attachment. Figure \@ref(fig:fig-THD-effattach) displays predicted outcomes by treatment and pre-exposure status (derived from the covariate model), revealing important heterogeneity. Among workers who were unaware of the Homer Fund before the survey, the video treatment produces a large positive effect (approximately 40% of an SD). Among workers already aware of the Homer Fund, treatment effects vanish; exposure to additional information does not further increase attachment. This pattern is theoretically sensible: emotional messages affect those learning something new more than those already informed.


```{r fig-THD-effattach, echo=FALSE, fig.cap = "Interpreting treatment effects on Home Depot job attachment by EHF pre-exposure status", out.width="70%", fig.align='center'}
THDattach_eff_plot
```

Examining individual components of the attachment index (Appendix \@ref(app-cov) and \@ref(app-full-wmt)), I find consistent positive effects of the video treatment across loyalty to coworkers, loyalty to employer, and willingness to recommend, although the employer loyalty effect is smaller and marginally significant.

For Home Depot, H3 is supported: EHF messages increase job attachment, particularly among previously unaware workers. The effect size is substantively meaningful. This occurs despite no improvement in financial security, suggesting the mechanism is symbolic or affective rather than material.


### Support for unionization

Figure \@ref(fig:fig-uv-thd) shows union vote intentions by treatment condition. Home Depot workers are generally skeptical of unions: only `r 100*round(summary_tab_uw_c$prounion,2)`%  of control respondents reporting a willingness to vote for a union and `r 100*round(summary_tab_uw_c$antiunion,2)`% voting against (the remainder answered "not sure").  This is substantially more anti-union than retail workers generally (Study 1 found `r round(100*genpop_engage_sum$union_support)`% would vote for a union) or even Walmart workers (see below). 

```{r fig-uv-thd,eval=TRUE, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Support for unionization by treatment status in the Home Depot sample", out.width="70%", fig.align='center'}

temp<-here::here('2_code', 'THD', '7_uiuv_summary_plots.R')
source(temp)
rm(temp)
uv_plot
```

The video treatment visibly shifts responses away from "for the union" toward "not sure"—but not toward greater opposition. The text treatment shows similar patterns but weaker.  On average, the video treatment makes respondents more _uncertain_ about their support for unionization.  Respondents answered rather than skipped the question, suggesting the video increased uncertainty rather than disinterest.

Table \@ref(tab:tab-uv) reports multinomial logistic regression results.  In the base model we see that video treatment, on average, produces an increase in the "not sure" responses, echoing Figure \@ref(fig:fig-uv-thd).  Once I account for pre-exposure, a clearer pattern emerges. Those aware of the EHF prior to the experiment were _already_ significantly less supportive of unions than the unexposed. Among workers unaware of the Homer Fund, both treatments significantly reduce pro-union responses, with effects concentrated in the video condition.  Including covariates that are predictive of pre-exposure does not alter conclusions.    

```{r tab-uv, eval=TRUE, echo = FALSE, warning = FALSE, tab.cap="Multinomial logit regression models on support for unionization "}

source(temp)
rm(temp)

multinom_tab

```

Figure \@ref(fig:fig-uveff) translates these logit coefficients into predicted probabilities by pre-exposure status. Among the previously unaware (left column), the video treatment more than halves predicted union support from about `r round(100*eff_probs$prob[1,"prob.For.the.union"])`% to `r round(100*eff_probs$prob[3,"prob.For.the.union"])`%. This effect does not come from increasing active opposition but rather from making workers uncertain. The proportion answering "not sure" grows from  `r round(100*eff_probs$prob[1,"prob.Not.sure"])`% to almost `r round(100*eff_probs$prob[3,"prob.Not.sure"])`%.

Among workers already aware of the Homer Fund (right column), treatment effects differ. The pre-exposed are already less supportive of unions on average, and additional exposure to Homer Fund messaging does not further shift reduce this low support.  But it does increase uncertainty from `r round(100*eff_probs$prob[4,"prob.Not.sure"])`% to almost `r round(100*eff_probs$prob[6,"prob.Not.sure"])`%

```{r fig-uveff, eval=TRUE, echo=FALSE, fig.height=8, fig.cap="Interpreting heterogeneous treatment effects on union support (Home Depot sample)", out.width="70%", fig.align='center'}
#dev.new(width = 6000, height = 1500, unit = "px")
print(mnl_eff_plot)

```

H4 is supported at Home Depot: EHF information reduces support for unionization. However, the mechanism is not converting pro-union workers to anti-union positions. Instead, exposure to EHF messaging increases ambivalence--workers who might have supported a union become uncertain. This could reflect several processes: EHF information reminds workers of employer benefits, raises doubts about what unions would add, or signals employer responsiveness that makes unions seem less necessary.  The concentration of effects among previously unaware workers is again theoretically sensible but has important implications: the Homer Fund may be most effective at shaping attitudes of workers who haven't yet developed strong attachments or opinions.

## Results: Study 3 (Walmart)

Study 3 follows an identical analytic approach with Walmart workers. Under H5 EHF effects depend on program generosity and cultural integration. Walmart's EHF should therefore produce weaker effects or backfire.

### Financial security

```{r}
ee.prop<-summarise(wmt.hq_wgt_f, 
          survey_mean(emergency_expense_num >0.5))
```

Walmart workers are notably more financially precarious than Home Depot workers, with `r round(100*(1-ee.prop$coef))`% expressing concern about their ability to meet a \$400 emergency expense, 25 percentage points higher than among Home Depot workers.  This aligns with other indicators: in our samples, 35% of Walmart respondents reported accessing government welfare programs in the past year versus 20% at Home Depot.

Table \@ref(tab:tab-finsec-wmt) displays OLS regression-based estimates of treatment effects on financial security. As at Home Depot, there are no detectable effects. The pre-exposed report greater financial resilience (0.1 scale points or 27% of a control group standard deviation), but treatment does not shift beliefs among either aware or unaware workers.

H1 remains unsupported. Across both firms, intensive, realistic EHF messages do not improve subjective financial security--the programs' stated purpose.

### Job attachment

In addition to feeling more financially precarious, Walmart respondents express lower baseline job attachment than Home Depot workers.  For example, the net promoter score among the Walmart control respondents was `r 100*round(nps[[1]],2)`%, seven percentage points lower than at Home Depot.^[Net promoter score is % promoters - % detractors for the recommend employer question, a common indicator of aggregate support.]  This suggests that Walmart workers are coming in to the survey with a more negative set of experiences and expectations about their employer than the Home Depot sample, consistent with the description of corporate culture from @sullMeasuringCultureLeading2019.  

Table \@ref(tab:tab-attachment-models-wmt) presents treatment effects on the attachment index. We continue to see that those pre-exposed to the EHF are more attached to their jobs, even after conditioning on predictors of EHF awareness. But the ACNT video treatment produces a small effect on job attachment that is indistinguishable from zero. Effects do not vary by pre-exposure.

```{r tab-attachment-models-wmt, eval=TRUE, echo = FALSE, tab.cap="Job attachment (Walmart)"}
temp<-here::here('2_code', 'Walmart', '8_attachment_models_WMT.R')
source(temp)
rm(temp)

model_print_attachment_hq
```

Examining individual components (Appendix \@ref(app-full-wmt)) shows similar null results across loyalty to coworkers, loyalty to employer, willingness to recommend, and quit intentions. The ACNT message simply does not move these attitudes.  H3 is not supported at Walmart. The null finding is not a failed replication, as there is evidence that the experiment worked as intended in the manipulation checks.  Rather, the sharp contrast with Home Depot provides evidence consistent with H5 (contingency).

Why might this be? There a several possibilities, including (1) The ACNT is just not generous enough to be meaningful to workers; (2) the lack of authentic employer promotion makes our adapted video seem disingenuous, or (3) workers perceive inconsistency between ACNT messaging and their broader experiences at Walmart. I cannot distinguish among these possibilities, but all align with CSR research on perceived sincerity.

These findings directly contradict H4. At Walmart, EHF messages reduce _opposition_ to unions rather than reducing support. This is the opposite of what we observed at Home Depot.

How can we explain this reversal? For workers at Walmart, the ACNT video may underscore workers' precarity and Walmart's inadequate response, making collective action seem more attractive rather than less. Or the video's emphasis on mutual aid may combine with their experience on to job to increase rather than decrease receptivity to unions.  But alternative mechanisms warrant consideration.  For example, the post-covid uptick in union activism may have affected how workers interpret employer-sponsored mutual aid programs. Although I cannot definitively identify the mechanisms, any explanation must account for the opposite effects on union attitudes across firms.

Table \@ref(tab:tab-results-summary) summarizes experimental results from Studies 2 and 3:

```{r tab-results-summary, echo=FALSE}
      caption = "Summary of Experimental Findings Across Firms",
      booktabs = TRUE) %>%
  kable_styling(latex_options = c("hold_position", "striped"),
                font_size = 10) %>%
  column_spec(1, width = "3.5cm") %>%
  column_spec(2, width = "4cm") %>%
  column_spec(3, width = "4cm") %>%
  column_spec(4, width = "2.5cm")
```

The results reveal a striking paradox and context dependence. At both firms, exposure to realistic EHF messages fails to improve perceived financial security (H1 rejected). Yet at Home Depot, these same message significantly increased job attachment and reduced union support among previously unaware workers (H3, H4 supported). Effects are stronger for video than text treatments, indicating that emotional, narrative messaging elicits stronger reactions than a factual description. This suggests EHFs messages operate through symbolic or affective channels, perhaps signaling workplace care, fostering perceived reciprocity, or invoking solidarity rather than credibly reducing economic precarity.   

At Walmart, the pattern reverses. ACNT messages produce no attachment gains (H3 rejected) and reduce opposition to unions rather than increasing it (H4 contradicted). This is consistent with H5: a culturally discordant EHF program highlights employer shortcomings rather than demonstrating support.  Nevertheless, a limitation of the present study is the absence of directly measured moderators through which EHF messages might generate attachment, beyond financial security.

These divergent effects cannot be attributed to differences in recruitment, measurement, or analysis approach.    The three-year gap between Study 2 (Fall 2021) and Study 3 (Fall 2024) does raises comparability concerns, as the intervening period witnessed high-profile unionization campaigns, potentially shifting attitudes toward unions and employers. Several considerations mitigate but do not eliminate this concern. First, our focus is on within-study experimental comparisons—treatment versus control—rather than cross-study level comparisons. I document that Walmart workers in our sample are more pro-union at baseline, which could reflect either temporal trends or persistent firm differences.  I cannot distinguish between these, but the experimental comparisons remain valid within each sample.  Second, union support appears to have been rising nationally since before the coronavirus pandemic [@ahlquistRiseUnionCurious2024;@sojournerAmericansFavorLabor2025], that is, the Home Depot survey occurred well into the period of broad opinion shifts around unions. Timing may add noise but does not obviously explain the pattern.

# Implications:  towards a theory of the contingent effects of internal CSR {#sec-framework}

The divergent findings between Home Depot and Walmart suggest that program characteristics and cultural context shape how workers interpret EHF programs. EHFs function as contingent governance tools, not universally effective loyalty-builders. From this starting point I propose a simple theoretical framework. I offer it not as tested theory but as a structured interpretation that organizes our results,  identifies measurement needs, and generates predictions for future research (see @lockeCaseInductiveTheory2007 on the role of inductive theory).

Organizational Support Theory (OST) provides a foundation for understanding worker reactions to inward CSR initiatives. OST holds that workers attribute coherent intentions, priorities, and values to large, complex organizations. They look to past treatment, HR practices, and work conditions as signals about how much their employer values them, so-called perceived organizational support (POS). POS evokes emotions and drives expectations about future treatment, which then determines loyalty and attachment [@eisenbergerPerceivedOrganizationalSupport1986; @eisenbergerPerceivedOrganizationalSupport2020]. Critically, in POS there can be a wedge between perceived intentions and material conditions. Workers can simultaneously believe "my employer cares about me" and "I'm financially vulnerable". Our null finding on financial security alongside increased attachment is consistent with this approach.

Recent research connects OST with CSR initiatives [@glavasEffectsPerceivedCorporate2014].  As noted above, CSR effects on employees depend on workers perceptions of motives. When CSR programs contradict other organizational practices, workers may interpret them as cynical and instrumental, undermining the program [@burbanoMitigatingGigRemote2022; @cassarIntentionsDoingGood2021; @doniaCSRAnyOther2019; @chengImpactCSRPerceptions2022]. This suggests that, rather than passively accepting managerial initiatives, workers actively evaluate whether these programs credibly demonstrate organizational support. Building on these insights, I add more specificity.  I propose that two programmatic dimensions structure worker perceptions: organizational consistency and situational adequacy.

Organizational consistency captures whether a program aligns with workers' broader experience of organizational practices and culture. Does the program fit with how management typically behaves? Are the goals and rhetoric around inward CSR consistent with the organization's priorities, as revealed through other practices, such as promotions, scheduling, benefits, and other CSR initiatives? When Home Depot employees encounter the Homer Fund, they evaluate it in the context of a workplace culture scoring relatively high on collaboration and respect [@sullMeasuringCultureLeading2019] in which all employees, including executives, are required to work a quarterly 8-hour retail shift.  Combined with extensive promotion and integration into the workplace, the Homer Fund is more likely to chime with workers' daily experiences. When Walmart employees encounter the ACNT, they assess it against a cost-control culture in which earlier commitments to improve scheduling practices appear to have been incompletely implemented [@schneiderHowUnpredictableWork2018].  Workers are more likely to perceive a disconnect between ACNT rhetoric and workers' experiences.

Situational adequacy captures whether a program communicates an understanding of the scale and nature of workers' actual challenges. Does the program offer support commensurate with the acknowledged need, organizational resources, and worker expectations of their employer? Situational adequacy does not require that workplace programs fully "solve" any problem they set out to address. But once an employer attempts to signal concern, a workplace program must marshal resources adequate to the task. Program generosity is not the only dimension of adequacy. An EHF that is cumbersome, slow, or frequently rejects applicants in need could fail to be situationally adequate, even with large grants.  Intensive outreach and generous EHF grants at Home Depot signal recognition that genuine emergencies are real threats to worker well-being. At Walmart, the existence of an EHF implies management knows its workforce struggles with financial shocks.  Yet ACNT maximum grants of \$1,500 combined with more restrictive eligibility and limited promotion among a population reporting elevated financial insecurity may be interpreted as tone deaf. 

These dimensions generate a framework for predicting internal CSR effects (Table \@ref(tab:csr-framework)). When programs demonstrate both organizational consistency and situational adequacy (resonant programs), they generate loyalty gains by credibly signaling support, consistent with OST theory. When programs lack both dimensions (hollow programs), they fail to generate loyalty and may backfire by highlighting organizational inadequacy.

(ref:csr-framework-cap) A Framework for Predicting Internal CSR Effects

\begin{table}[ht]
\centering
\caption{(ref:csr-framework-cap)}
\label{tab:csr-framework}
\begin{tabular}{p{3cm}|p{5.5cm}|p{5.5cm}}
\hline
& \textbf{High Situational Adequacy} & \textbf{Low Situational Adequacy} \\
\hline
\textbf{High Organizational Consistency} & 
\textbf{Resonant programs:}  Effective signal of organizational support increasing attachment. Workers perceive alignment between rhetoric and reality.   \textit{(Example: Homer Fund)} & 
\textbf{Well-intentioned insufficiency:} May generate modest positive effects or null effects. Workers perceive support but also limitations. Program may be oversubscribed \\
\hline
